1using System;
2using System.Collections.Generic;
3​
4namespace TechnicalIndicators
5{
6 public readonly record struct CandleData(DateTime Timestamp, decimal Open, decimal High, decimal Low, decimal Close, long Volume);
7​
8 /// <summary>
9 /// Calculates the Exponential Moving Average (EMA), which places greater weight and significance on the most recent data points.
10 /// </summary>
11 public class ExponentialMovingAverage
12 {
13 public int Period { get; }
14 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
15​
16 /// <summary>
17 /// Initializes a new instance of the <see cref="ExponentialMovingAverage"/> class.
18 /// </summary>
19 /// <param name="period">The lookback period. Must be greater than 0.</param>
20 public ExponentialMovingAverage(int period)
21 {
22 // Rationale: A period of 0 or less is mathematically undefined for EMA smoothing.
23 if (period <= 0)
24 throw new ArgumentOutOfRangeException(nameof(period), "Period must be greater than 0");
25 Period = period;
26 }
27​
28 /// <summary>
29 /// Computes the EMA values for the provided time series.
30 /// </summary>
31 /// <param name="candles">Input collection of candle data.</param>
32 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
33 {
34 Values.Clear();
35 var candleList = new List<CandleData>(candles);
36 if (candleList.Count == 0) return;
37​
38 // Rationale: If Period is 1, EMA is identical to the price itself (no smoothing).
39 if (Period == 1)
40 {
41 foreach (var candle in candleList)
42 Values.Add(candle.Close);
43 return;
44 }
45​
46 // Rationale: The smoothing factor 'k' determines how much weight is given to the current price.
47 // Formula: k = 2 / (N + 1). A smaller N results in a larger k (more weight to recent data).
48 decimal k = 2.0m / (Period + 1);
49 decimal? prevEma = null;
50​
51 for (int i = 0; i < candleList.Count; i++)
52 {
53 // Rationale: Insufficient data to calculate EMA.
54 if (i < Period - 1)
55 {
56 Values.Add(null);
57 continue;
58 }
59​
60 // Rationale: The first EMA value is typically initialized using the Simple Moving Average (SMA).
61 if (i == Period - 1)
62 {
63 decimal sum = 0;
64 for (int j = 0; j < Period; j++)
65 sum += candleList[i - j].Close;
66 prevEma = sum / Period;
67 Values.Add(prevEma);
68 continue;
69 }
70​
71 // Rationale: Classic recursive EMA formula: EMA_today = (Price_today - EMA_yesterday) * k + EMA_yesterday.
72 if (prevEma == null)
73 {
74 Values.Add(null);
75 }
76 else
77 {
78 decimal ema = (candleList[i].Close - prevEma.Value) * k + prevEma.Value;
79 Values.Add(ema);
80 prevEma = ema;
81 }
82 }
83 }
84​
85 /// <summary>
86 /// Static convenience method to calculate EMA.
87 /// </summary>
88 /// <param name="candles">Input collection of candle data.</param>
89 /// <param name="period">The lookback period.</param>
90 /// <returns>A list of nullable decimal values representing the EMA.</returns>
91 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period)
92 {
93 var ema = new ExponentialMovingAverage(period);
94 ema.Calculate(candles);
95 return ema.Values;
96 }
97​
98 /// <summary>
99 /// Helper to calculate EMA from a list of values instead of candles (used by MACD etc).
100 /// </summary>
101 public static void CalculateFromValues(List<decimal?> source, int period, List<decimal?> results)
102 {
103 // Implementation logic mirrors Calculate but handles nullable decimals
104 // ... (omitted for brevity in doc comment summary)
105 // See Calculate method for core logic.
106 results.Clear();
107​
108 if (source.Count == 0 || period <= 0) return;
109​
110 decimal k = 2.0m / (period + 1);
111 decimal? prevEma = null;
112 int validCount = 0;
113​
114 for (int i = 0; i < source.Count; i++)
115 {
116 if (!source[i].HasValue)
117 {
118 results.Add(null);
119 continue;
120 }
121​
122 validCount++;
123 decimal currentValue = source[i]!.Value;
124​
125 if (validCount < period)
126 {
127 results.Add(null);
128 continue;
129 }
130​
131 if (validCount == period)
132 {
133 decimal sum = 0;
134 int count = 0;
135 for (int j = i; j >= 0 && count < period; j--)
136 {
137 if (source[j].HasValue)
138 {
139 sum += source[j]!.Value;
140 count++;
141 }
142 }
143 prevEma = count > 0 ? sum / count : (decimal?)null;
144 results.Add(prevEma);
145 continue;
146 }
147​
148 if (prevEma.HasValue)
149 {
150 decimal ema = (currentValue - prevEma.Value) * k + prevEma.Value;
151 results.Add(ema);
152 prevEma = ema;
153 }
154 else
155 {
156 results.Add(null);
157 }
158 }
159 }
160 }
161}

1// =============================================================================
2// Logic Breakdown (ExponentialMovingAverage)
3// =============================================================================
4//
5// This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6// Exponential Moving Average (EMA) technical indicator.
7// We explain *why* code is written this way and *how* data transforms
8// line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
9//
10// [Core Concepts]
11//
12// 1. Weighting
13// [Why] Simple Moving Averages (SMA) treat the price 100 days ago equal to today.
14// This causes lag.
15// [What] EMA gives more weight to recent prices and less to older prices.
16//
17// 2. The Multiplier (k)
18// [Formula] k = 2 / (Period + 1)
19// [Example] Period 9 -> k = 0.2 (20% weight to today).
20// [Effect] Larger 'k' (Shorter Period) = Faster reaction to recent price.
21// Smaller 'k' (Longer Period) = Smoother line, slower reaction.
22//
23// 3. Recursive Calculation
24// [Formula] CurrentEMA = (CurrentPrice - PrevEMA) * k + PrevEMA
25// [Meaning] Take the old average, see how far off today's price is,
26// multiply that error by 'k', and add it to update the average.
27//
28// [Visual Plan]
29// Period = 3 (k = 0.5)
30//
31// Day 1: Close 10. (No prev EMA) -> Wait.
32// Day 2: Close 11. (No prev EMA) -> Wait.
33// Day 3: Close 12. (Init SMA) -> (10+11+12)/3 = 11.
34// Day 4: Close 14. (EMA Calc) -> (14 - 11) * 0.5 + 11 = 1.5 + 11 = 12.5.
35//
36// =============================================================================
37​
38using System;
39using System.Collections.Generic;
40​
41namespace TechnicalIndicators
42{
43 // =============================================================================
44 // Logic Explanation: OHLCV Data Container
45 // =============================================================================
46 public readonly record struct CandleData(DateTime Timestamp, decimal Open, decimal High, decimal Low, decimal Close, long Volume);
47​
48 // =============================================================================
49 // Logic Explanation: EMA Indicator Class
50 // =============================================================================
51 public class ExponentialMovingAverage
52 {
53 // -------------------------------------------------------------
54 // Logic Explanation: Configuration
55 // -------------------------------------------------------------
56 public int Period { get; }
57 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
58​
59 // =============================================================================
60 // Logic Explanation: Constructor
61 // =============================================================================
62 public ExponentialMovingAverage(int period)
63 {
64 if (period <= 0)
65 throw new ArgumentOutOfRangeException(nameof(period), "Period must be greater than 0");
66 Period = period;
67 }
68​
69 // =============================================================================
70 // Logic Explanation: Main Calculation Method (From Candles)
71 // =============================================================================
72 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
73 {
74 // -------------------------------------------------------------
75 // Step 1: Cleanup & Validation
76 // -------------------------------------------------------------
77 Values.Clear();
78 var candleList = new List<CandleData>(candles);
79 if (candleList.Count == 0) return;
80​
81 // Edge Case: Period 1 means no averaging (just the raw price)
82 if (Period == 1)
83 {
84 foreach (var candle in candleList)
85 Values.Add(candle.Close);
86 return;
87 }
88​
89 // -------------------------------------------------------------
90 // Step 2: Calculate Multiplier 'k'
91 //
92 // [Why] Pre-calculating this constant saves CPU cycles inside the loop.
93 // -------------------------------------------------------------
94 decimal k = 2.0m / (Period + 1);
95 decimal? prevEma = null;
96​
97 for (int i = 0; i < candleList.Count; i++)
98 {
99 // -------------------------------------------------------------
100 // Phase A: Insufficient Data (Leading Nulls)
101 // -------------------------------------------------------------
102 if (i < Period - 1)
103 {
104 Values.Add(null);
105 continue;
106 }
107​
108 // -------------------------------------------------------------
109 // Phase B: Initialization (The First EMA)
110 //
111 // [Why] EMA is recursive (uses Yesterday's value). What do we use
112 // for the very first day?
113 // [Standard] Use the SMA (Simple Average) of the first 'Period' bars.
114 // -------------------------------------------------------------
115 if (i == Period - 1)
116 {
117 decimal sum = 0;
118 for (int j = 0; j < Period; j++)
119 sum += candleList[i - j].Close;
120
121 prevEma = sum / Period;
122 Values.Add(prevEma);
123 continue;
124 }
125​
126 // -------------------------------------------------------------
127 // Phase C: Standard Calculation (Feedback Loop)
128 //
129 // [Logic]
130 // 1. Take difference (Price - OldAvg).
131 // 2. Weight it by 'k'.
132 // 3. Add to OldAvg to get NewAvg.
133 // -------------------------------------------------------------
134 if (prevEma != null) // Should always be true if Phase B worked
135 {
136 decimal ema = (candleList[i].Close - prevEma.Value) * k + prevEma.Value;
137 Values.Add(ema);
138 prevEma = ema;
139 }
140 else
141 {
142 // Fallback for safety (though theoretically unreachable here)
143 Values.Add(null);
144 }
145 }
146 }
147​
148 // =============================================================================
149 // Logic Explanation: Static Convenience Wrapper
150 // =============================================================================
151 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period)
152 {
153 var ema = new ExponentialMovingAverage(period);
154 ema.Calculate(candles);
155 return ema.Values;
156 }
157​
158 // =============================================================================
159 // Logic Explanation: Helper Method (Calculate from Numbers directly)
160 //
161 // [Why] Sometimes we need an EMA of something other than Close Price.
162 // (e.g., EMA of RSI, EMA of Volume, EMA of another EMA).
163 // This is used by indicators like MACD, DEMA, TEMA.
164 //
165 // [Inputs]
166 // source: List<decimal?> which might contain nulls itself!
167 // results: Output list to populate.
168 // =============================================================================
169 public static void CalculateFromValues(List<decimal?> source, int period, List<decimal?> results)
170 {
171 results.Clear();
172​
173 if (source.Count == 0 || period <= 0) return;
174​
175 decimal k = 2.0m / (period + 1);
176 decimal? prevEma = null;
177 int validCount = 0; // Tracks how many non-null numbers we've seen
178​
179 for (int i = 0; i < source.Count; i++)
180 {
181 // -------------------------------------------------------------
182 // Step A: Handle Missing Data in Source
183 //
184 // [Why] If the source (e.g., RSI) is null/invalid, the EMA
185 // of it is also null/invalid.
186 // -------------------------------------------------------------
187 if (!source[i].HasValue)
188 {
189 results.Add(null);
190 continue;
191 }
192​
193 // Found a valid number
194 validCount++;
195 decimal currentValue = source[i]!.Value;
196​
197 // -------------------------------------------------------------
198 // Step B: Wait for Period Length (of VALID data)
199 //
200 // [Why] If Period=10, we need 10 Actual Numbers, not just 10 indices.
201 // -------------------------------------------------------------
202 if (validCount < period)
203 {
204 results.Add(null);
205 continue;
206 }
207​
208 // -------------------------------------------------------------
209 // Step C: Bootstrap (First Valid Point) with SMA
210 // -------------------------------------------------------------
211 if (validCount == period)
212 {
213 decimal sum = 0;
214 int count = 0;
215
216 // Look backwards to sum the last 'period' valid values
217 // Note: This loop is a bit complex because source has gaps (nulls).
218 for (int j = i; j >= 0 && count < period; j--)
219 {
220 if (source[j].HasValue)
221 {
222 sum += source[j]!.Value;
223 count++;
224 }
225 }
226
227 prevEma = count > 0 ? sum / count : (decimal?)null;
228 results.Add(prevEma);
229 continue;
230 }
231​
232 // -------------------------------------------------------------
233 // Step D: Recursive Calculation
234 // -------------------------------------------------------------
235 if (prevEma.HasValue)
236 {
237 decimal ema = (currentValue - prevEma.Value) * k + prevEma.Value;
238 results.Add(ema);
239 prevEma = ema;
240 }
241 else
242 {
243 results.Add(null);
244 }
245 }
246 }
247 }
248}

1class ExponentialMovingAverage:
2 """
3 Calculates the Exponential Moving Average (EMA).
4​
5 Attributes:
6 period (int): The lookback period (N).
7 values (List[Optional[float]]): The calculated EMA values.
8 """
9 def __init__(self, period):
10 """
11 Initializes the EMA calculator.
12​
13 Args:
14 period (int): Lookback period. Must be > 0.
15
16 Raises:
17 ValueError: If period <= 0.
18 """
19 # Rationale: Mathematical requirement for smoothing period.
20 if period <= 0:
21 raise ValueError("period")
22 self.period = period
23 self.values = []
24​
25 def calculate(self, candles):
26 """
27 Computes the EMA values.
28​
29 Args:
30 candles (List[dict]): Candle data with 'close' key.
31 """
32 self.values.clear()
33 if len(candles) == 0:
34 return
35​
36 # Rationale: Single point average is the point itself.
37 if self.period == 1:
38 for c in candles:
39 self.values.append(c['close'])
40 return
41​
42 # Rationale: Smoothing factor k = 2 / (N+1).
43 k = 2.0 / (self.period + 1)
44 prev_ema = None
45​
46 for i in range(len(candles)):
47 # Rationale: Wait until enough data is gathered.
48 if i < self.period - 1:
49 self.values.append(None)
50 continue
51​
52 # Rationale: First valid EMA is initialized as SMA.
53 if i == self.period - 1:
54 s = sum(candles[i - j]['close'] for j in range(self.period))
55 prev_ema = s / self.period
56 self.values.append(prev_ema)
57 continue
58​
59 # Rationale: Recursive calculation using previous value.
60 if prev_ema is None:
61 self.values.append(None)
62 else:
63 ema = (candles[i]['close'] - prev_ema) * k + prev_ema
64 self.values.append(ema)
65 prev_ema = ema
66​
67def calculate(candles, period):
68 """
69 Static convenience wrapper for EMA.
70​
71 Args:
72 candles (List[dict]): Input data.
73 period (int): Lookback period.
74​
75 Returns:
76 List[Optional[float]]: Calculated EMA values.
77 """
78 ema = ExponentialMovingAverage(period)
79 ema.calculate(candles)
80 return ema.values

1# =============================================================================
2# Logic Breakdown (ExponentialMovingAverage)
3# =============================================================================
4#
5# This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6# Exponential Moving Average (EMA). We explain *why* code is written this way
7# and *how* data transforms line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
8#
9# [Core Concepts]
10# 1. Weighted History
11# Unlike Simple Moving Average (SMA) which gives equal weight to all previous N bars,
12# EMA applies more weight to the most recent price.
13# [Why] To reduce "lag" and react faster to recent market changes.
14#
15# 2. Recursive Calculation
16# EMA relies on its own previous value.
17# EMA_today = (Price_current * K) + (EMA_prev * (1 - K))
18# [Why] Efficient O(1) update step. No need to re-scan old data.
19#
20# 3. The Smoothing Factor (K)
21# K = 2 / (Period + 1)
22# - Shorter Period -> Higher K -> More weight on recent price (Faster)
23# - Longer Period -> Lower K -> More weight on history (Smoother)
24#
25# =============================================================================
26​
27# -------------------------------------------------------------
28# Type-Level Explanation: ExponentialMovingAverage (class)
29#
30# [Why] Stateful calculation required. Needs to remember 'prev_ema'.
31# [What] A recursive trend filter.
32# [How] Calculates a moving average by applying a smoothing factor (K) to the most recent price, giving it more weight than older prices. Uses recursion to update value efficiently.
33# [Who] Trend Following strategies, MACD, Bollinger Bands.
34# [Where] Heap (Class).
35# -------------------------------------------------------------
36class ExponentialMovingAverage:
37​
38 # -------------------------------------------------------------
39 # Logic Explanation: Indicator Configuration (Public Properties)
40 #
41 # [Why]
42 # Allow users to adjust the "speed" of the average.
43 #
44 # [What]
45 # - Period: The number of data points to approximate.
46 # -------------------------------------------------------------
47​
48 # -------------------------------------------------------------
49 # Constructor: __init__
50 #
51 # [Input]
52 # - period: int (Lookback setting)
53 #
54 # [Why]
55 # Initialize implementation constants.
56 # -------------------------------------------------------------
57 def __init__(self, period):
58
59 # -------------------------------------------------------------
60 # Logic Step 1: Input Validation
61 #
62 # [Decision]
63 # Is the period positive?
64 #
65 # [True Branch: Invalid]
66 # - Raise error. Period must be >= 1.
67 # -------------------------------------------------------------
68 if period <= 0:
69 raise ValueError(f"Period must be greater than 0. Received: {period}")
70​
71 # -------------------------------------------------------------
72 # Variable Definition: Period
73 # [Role] Configuration setting.
74 # -------------------------------------------------------------
75 self.period = period
76​
77 # -------------------------------------------------------------
78 # Variable Definition: Output Storage
79 # [Role] Stores the sequence of calculated EMA values.
80 # [Type] list (Dynamic Array)
81 # -------------------------------------------------------------
82 self.values = []
83​
84​
85 # =============================================================================
86 # IPO: calculate
87 # =============================================================================
88 #
89 # [Input]
90 # - candles: list[dict] (must contain 'close')
91 #
92 # [Process]
93 # 1. Clear State.
94 # 2. Compute Smoothing Factor (K).
95 # 3. Iterate Time Series:
96 # - Phase A: Wait (Not enough data).
97 # - Phase B: Seed (First value = SMA).
98 # - Phase C: Recurse (EMA = Price*K + Prev*(1-K)).
99 #
100 # [Output]
101 # - None (populates self.values)
102 # =============================================================================
103 def calculate(self, candles):
104
105 # -------------------------------------------------------------
106 # Logic Step 1: Reset
107 # [Why] Allow re-use of the instance.
108 # -------------------------------------------------------------
109 self.values.clear()
110​
111 # -------------------------------------------------------------
112 # Logic Step 2: Empty Check
113 # -------------------------------------------------------------
114 count = len(candles)
115 if count == 0:
116 return
117​
118 # -------------------------------------------------------------
119 # Logic Step 3: Identity Optimization
120 #
121 # [Decision]
122 # Is period == 1?
123 #
124 # [True Branch: Identity]
125 # - EMA(1) is just the price itself.
126 # - Copy close prices directly.
127 #
128 # [False Branch: Calculate]
129 # - Proceed to recursive logic.
130 # -------------------------------------------------------------
131 if self.period == 1:
132 for c in candles:
133 self.values.append(c['close'])
134 return
135​
136 # -------------------------------------------------------------
137 # Variable Definition: Smoothing Factor (k)
138 # [Visual]
139 # Period = 9 -> k = 2/10 = 0.2
140 # Period = 19 -> k = 2/20 = 0.1
141 # [Why] Pre-calculate constant to avoid repeated division.
142 # -------------------------------------------------------------
143 k = 2.0 / (self.period + 1)
144
145 # -------------------------------------------------------------
146 # Variable Definition: Previous EMA (prev_ema)
147 # [Role] Accumulator / State Carry.
148 # -------------------------------------------------------------
149 prev_ema = None
150​
151 # -------------------------------------------------------------
152 # Logic Step 4: Iteration Loop
153 #
154 # [Why] Process sequential data.
155 # -------------------------------------------------------------
156 for i in range(count):
157
158 # -------------------------------------------------------------
159 # Variable Definition: Close Price
160 # -------------------------------------------------------------
161 close_price = candles[i]['close']
162​
163 # -------------------------------------------------------------
164 # Logic Step 4.1: Insufficient Data
165 #
166 # [Decision]
167 # Have we reached the minimum data points needed to start?
168 # (i < period - 1)
169 #
170 # [True Branch: Waiting]
171 # - Pad with None.
172 # - Continue to next bar.
173 # -------------------------------------------------------------
174 if i < self.period - 1:
175 self.values.append(None)
176 continue
177​
178 # -------------------------------------------------------------
179 # Logic Step 4.2: Seeding (First Value)
180 #
181 # [Decision]
182 # Is this the EXACT moment we have enough data?
183 # (i == period - 1)
184 #
185 # [True Branch: Seed]
186 # - Calculate SMA of the first 'period' bars.
187 # - Why SMA? Because we don't have a "previous EMA" yet.
188 # SMA serves as a reasonable starting guess.
189 # [Visual]
190 # [P1, P2, P3] -> SMA -> EMA_Start
191 # -------------------------------------------------------------
192 if i == self.period - 1:
193 # Calculate SMA for the initial period
194 sum_sq = 0.0
195 # Inner loop to sum the initial window
196 for j in range(self.period):
197 sum_sq += candles[i - j]['close']
198
199 prev_ema = sum_sq / self.period
200 self.values.append(prev_ema)
201 continue
202​
203 # -------------------------------------------------------------
204 # Logic Step 4.3: Recursive Calculation
205 #
206 # [Why] Apply the exponential weighting.
207 # [Formula]
208 # EMA = (Price - Prev) * k + Prev
209 #
210 # [Visual]
211 # Prev=100, Price=110, k=0.1
212 # Diff = 10
213 # Delta = 10 * 0.1 = 1
214 # EMA = 100 + 1 = 101
215 # -------------------------------------------------------------
216 ema = (close_price - prev_ema) * k + prev_ema
217 self.values.append(ema)
218
219 # Update state for next iteration
220 prev_ema = ema
221​
222​
223# =============================================================================
224# Functional Wrapper (Procedural Interface)
225# =============================================================================
226def calculate(candles, period):
227 """
228 Computes Exponential Moving Average (EMA).
229
230 :param candles: list of dictionaries, each containing 'close'.
231 :param period: Integer, lookback period.
232 :return: list of EMA values.
233 """
234
235 # -------------------------------------------------------------
236 # Step 1: Instantiation
237 # [Why] Create the calculator.
238 # -------------------------------------------------------------
239 instance = ExponentialMovingAverage(period)
240
241 # -------------------------------------------------------------
242 # Step 2: Execution
243 # [Why] Run the algorithm.
244 # -------------------------------------------------------------
245 instance.calculate(candles)
246
247 # -------------------------------------------------------------
248 # Step 3: Extraction
249 # [Why] Return the result.
250 # -------------------------------------------------------------
251 return instance.values
